Posts.Content: Hi ladies  Reading through some of the messages on here to people's reactions made me realise it wasn't just me getting these reactions and people saying things before there brain is engaged lol I can relate to what some of your were saying although I had Breast cancer. This may sound strange in some ways I count myself as lucky because my cancer got found very early and other than having to have a mastectomy and reconstructive surgery I didn't have to have any other treatment (thank god for mammograms), don't get me wrong the surgery wasn't a walk in the park it's very hard to go through as you all know. But when I look in the mirror it's not my Body anymore as I how have one boob got north and one going south, I'm sure some of you ladies can get this feeling and I think why me!! but then I think well I'm alive and I will my grandson grow up. One of ways I cope with it a lot of the time is having a very weird sense of humour with my friends and work colleagues (I work in a small meatal health team as they get weird sense of humour) but some people who don't know you would look and think how can your joke about cancer, it's a way of coping. Best wishes to all you lovely ladies Julie X x
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: Hi there Sorry to hear your having a bit of a bad time after your surgery. I found I was sore for a few weeks after my mastectomy once I had my drains out after a few weeks things became a little easier. Your breast care nurse is right it takes time for things to settle down but don't try to push yourself to much look after yourself and take it easy pamper yourself and let other people do things to help you. I found I got down but things will get better hun it just takes time talk to the Macmillan nurses and take any support they offer you. I didn't think I would ever get there after my op in August but I'm now back at work. Look after yourself and take care. Wishing you all the very best  Jules X x
Posts.Title: 18 days post surgery and very sore / tender

Posts.Content: Hi Lou I was given I surgical bra to stop mine from moving and I had to wear for around 6 weeks my consultant put on in after surgery, I hope that your new consultant gets it sorted out or you.
Posts.Title: breast expander has moved

Posts.Content: Hi Lou I agree with mistymoley  After my mastectomy my consultant did my reconstruction with the expander implant and used tissue matrix (this is a natural tissue) as well he told me that this is like a bra support inside the body and helps to keep the implant in place I and had two drains in place for a couple of weeks. You should of been told about the surgical bra I believe you can get them on line. I under the care of Lincoln and have found them very supportive and caring. I found the first doctor wasn't very helpful and wasn't going to do reconstruction straight away and I was very unhappy and upset as you can imagine so the sister in charge suggest a 2nd opinion which I got and I now I have brilliant consultant, explain to your new consultant how you feel and talk to the nursing staff and are there to help you and talk on your behalf. I can really relate to now you are feeling. I hope you get everything sorted out Hun x
Posts.Title: breast expander has moved

Posts.Content: Hi Lou I hope you get it sorted out with your new consultant, I had mine filled the other week and haven't had any problems as yet but I have found the it aches and feels very heavy at times I'm due to see my consultant again next month.
Posts.Title: breast expander has moved

Posts.Content: Hi  I had my mastectomy in August I had my drains in for about 2 week and a tight like surgical bra I have to wear for about 4 weeks maybe longer to make sure the implant didn't move. Once you have healed sports bras are great as are Geine Bras. I'm now back at work on a phased return.  I pod is a good idea as is ear plugs to block out any noise and and eye mask to block out any light I found both of these a god send. PJs are better than a nighty, baby wipes, mints, a small cushion to put under the arm of the side your having your breast taken off. Just take each day at a time and good luck with the op. Julie X x
Posts.Title: Preparation For Mastectomy & Recon on Monday - Advice please ?

Posts.Content: hi has anyone else been made to feel that because they hadn't had any other treatment after a mastectomy then they should get to work quicker. I had my surgery about 8 weeks ago and my doctor signed me off for another 3 weeks due to the nature of my job. I had my right breast removed and a reconstructive surgery done at the same time, my consultant told me that I need more sugary next year on my left breast as part of my cancer treatment but I was had to feel like this unimportant and cosmetic, I spoke the the breast clinical whose looking after me and they said I could get a letter regarding this, but I don't feel I should have to do this... the best of it is I work in the NHS!!!!
Posts.Title: Work issues

Posts.Content: UPDATE Hi ladies Well the nurse I spoke to a the breast clinical the over day did exactly what she said she was going to do and I got the letter from My consultant this morning to advised the trust (mangement) of the major surgery I had in August and that I have to avoid major physical activity and try to avoid any chest trauma to my chest for 3 months he also put that I need more surgery next year as part go my cancer treatment and after that I will need about 6 weeks off after this. Spot on consultant or what. I also had appointment with one of the nurses for some one to one and she was brilliant and very understanding and even better she doesn't work for the some trust I work for which gives me more confident that want ever .I say to her stays with her and she has oftered to support me though this time. Just got my appointment over the phone with OH next week. So I'm how feeling a little more positive today. thank you for your support ladies X x

Posts.Content: Hi I was give I heart shaped cushion by the Macmillan nurses in Lincoln to use and I also found pillows put under my arm helped at night time. I found once I didn't have to wear my sugcial bra that Genie bras were great to wear in bed and through out the day and after doing so research and buying no end of bras to try and find something comfortable, I have found sports bras both underwire as they given more support if you need a prostices inside your bra (so your normal breast is the same as your implant) or non underwire to wear around the house or wearing lose clothes. I hope this is helpful.
Posts.Title: Bras after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi I had the radioactive injection prior to my op and had some lymph nodes removed and I didn't had to have any more removed after surgery. I to found that it was hard to move my arm for a while but it gets better with time, I also had some burning to begain with but this has now passed. Good luck hope all goes well.
